Unless we have a system for purging them, they live on.  

Here’s how an Essentialist would approach that closet.  

EXPLORE AND EVALUATE  

Instead of asking, “Will I wear this someday?”  

You ask tougher questions: “Do I love this?”  

And “Do I look great in it?”  

And “Do I wear this often?”  

If the answer is no, eliminate it.  

In your life, ask, “Will this effort contribute to my goal?”  

Part One of this book helps you identify those activities.  

ELIMINATE  

Let’s say you have clothes in “must keep” and “get rid of.”  

Are you ready to send the “get rid of” pile away?  

There is a feeling of sunk-cost bias.  

We value our possessions more than they are worth.  

This makes it harder to let go.  

If you’re unsure, ask: “If I didn’t own this, how much would I pay?”  

This usually helps you decide.  

It’s not enough to identify non-contributing activities.  

You must actively eliminate those that do not contribute.  

Part Two of this book shows you how to eliminate nonessentials.  

It also teaches you how to gain respect while doing it.  

EXECUTE  

To keep your closet tidy, establish a routine.  

You need one large bag for items to throw away.  

And a small pile for items to keep.  

You need to know the process to maintain organization.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** An Essentialist approach involves exploring, evaluating, eliminating, and executing to focus on activities that contribute the most to one's goals.
